Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Investigating the Influence of Sea-surface Variability on Ice Sheet Mass Balance and Outlet Glacier Behavior using Records from Disko Bugt, West Greenland
Award.AbstractNarration: This project will further understanding of ocean-ice-atmosphere interaction around the Jakobshavn Isbrae and Disko Bay region of west Greenland, with a particular focus on the role of sea surface temperature and sea ice variability in modulating past outlet glacier behavior and ice sheet/cap mass balance (snowfall and melt) over the past two centuries. The PIs will reconstruct past environmental conditions in the Disko and Baffin Bay region based on new glaciochemical and stratigraphic records from three 100-m deep ice cores, several firn cores, and geophysical studies from three sites surrounding Disko Bay. Their field activities will commence in 2013 with the primary ice coring activity in 2014 and lab and computation work following to derive climate reconstructions from the cores. The results will complement recent glaciological studies of regional ice dynamic behavior, as well as recent paleoceanographic and glacial geologic reconstructions of conditions from this area and era. Das and Frey will each supervise a full-time PhD student, and Evans will supervise undergraduate research assistants and senior theses. A high school science teacher will also participate in the field work and interact with students at his school in Massachusetts as well as from the ice.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Recent changes, including the dramatic speedups of outlet glaciers, and increased rates of surface melting, have increased Greenland?s contribution to sea-level rise from near zero in the 1990s to a large negative imbalance today. Poor knowledge of the processes driving these changes is one of the main limitations on prediction of future ice sheet contributions to sea level rise. An increasing number of observations point towards the influence of coupled ocean-ice-atmospheric processes, but most studies are limited to the past few decades restricting our ability to extrapolate these relationships over longer time periods, given their high inter-annual variability. This project integrates new and existing ice core data from the Greenland ice sheet (GIS) and coastal Greenland ice caps, with remotely sensed observations and modeled climate output, to reconstruct past ice sheet and ice cap surface mass balance (snowfall and melt/runoff), and investigates how these and other glaciochemical variables relate to coastal climate (e.g. temperature, sea ice coverage and marine primary productivity) to better understand what controls the behavior of the GIS over decadal to millennial time-scales. The project involved close collaboration between the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, Wheaton College, DRI, the University of Washington and Clark University.  

 

Key findings include: (1) Ice cores from the Nuussuaq Peninsula, in the Baffin Bay region, provide a unique record of coastal west Greenland climate over recent decades to centuries, independent and not always corresponding to records from the nearby western flank of the Greenland ice sheet (which is dominated by moisture input originating from southeast Greenland coast rather than west Greenland) (Osman et al., 2017a and 2017b; Osman et al., 2018, in review; Osman et al, in prep.)   Work is ongoing to directly connect the dramatic precipitation trends recorded in the Nuussuaq ice core, changes that are much larger than observed from inland Greenland records, to ice marginal behavior and variability in nearby open water conditions over the last millennium (Osman et al, in prep).  (2) Ice core records from the western flank of the Greenland ice sheet and Nuussuaq Peninsula provide a unique record of past ice sheet surface melt, demonstrating recent increases in melt are exceptional within a longer-term context, and also providing the first ice core-constrained multi-century record of past Greenland runoff. Results show that Greenland melt and runoff have steadily increased since the mid-18th century, closely following the onset of postindustrial Arctic warming, and that only within the last few decades has Greenland runoff surpassed the range of natural variability.  (Trusel et al., 2018). (3) Records from an array spanning the GIS show that marine biogenic aerosols are well preserved in ice cores (Osman et al., 2017), and that they provide a unique record of marine productivity in the subarctic Atlantic, rather than being a sea-ice proxy, as previously interpreted. These records furthermore show productivity in this region has declined significantly over the industrial-era (Osman et al., 2018, in review.)

 

Outcomes of the project have been widely disseminated at national and international science conferences (>20 abstracts at AGU, EGU, IGS, IPICS, among others); through institutional seminars, outreach and engagement activities (>50 activities); and in the primary, peer-reviewed literature (three manuscripts published or in press; two in review; two in preparation). The new multi-century reconstruction of past Greenland melt and catchment-scale runoff (Trusel et al., 2018), showing a rapid non-linear increase in response to post-industrial Arctic warming represents a major contribution to the field, and will be useful not only to glaciologists, but to oceanographers and others interested in the freshwater and associated geochemical and sedimentary fluxes from Greenland to the ocean, as well as the public and policy makers concerned with Greenland mass loss and sea level rise. The new multi-century reconstruction of North Atlantic marine primary productivity (Osman et al., in review) showing a productivity decline over the industrial era, potentially in response to a slowdown in AMOC (itself potentially in response to an increase in Greenland melt) represents a major contribution that will be useful to the climatological, oceanographic and biological scientific communities, as well as the public and fisheries managers.  More generally, the temporal perspective of our results highlights the usefulness of ice-core records in providing high-resolution (~annual), multi-decadal to millennial-scale records of environmental change prior to the relatively brief observational era. Our results illustrate the rapid and recent changes in the Arctic marine and ice environments in the late 20th and early 21st centuries, with many changes now falling outside the range of natural variability.  These results have important implications for understanding ongoing GIS mass loss, and Greenland?s potential future contribution to sea-level rise. This work contributed to the education and training of two graduate students at MIT-WHOI (M. Osman and L. Stevens), one post-doc at WHOI (L. Trusel), and secondary school science teacher (M. Bingham) and students (~many) at Milton Academy.
